conversation.text: Hi there have you ever made apple butter before?
evidence: Wash, peel, core, and quarter the apples
Wash, peel, core, and quarter the apples

conversation.text: No, but I'd like to try it.
Awesome, so first you need to take a bunch of apples, was them, peel them and then core them. Do you have a corer?
evidence: Wash the apples first, then peel them. After this, you can core them

conversation.text: Yes, I do.
Okay perfect, after coring the apples cut them into quarters and then put them into a large pot and add apple cider.
evidence: Put the apples into a large pot first, then add the apple cider.

conversation.text: Just did that. Do I need to add water to the pot or just pure apple cider?
No, do not add any water, just pure apple cider. Put the stove on high heat and bring the apples and apple cider to a boil and then immediately reduce heat to low and let simmer for 20 minutes.
evidence: Turn the heat up to high, and let the cider come to a boil.
Immediately reduce the heat to low, and let the apples and cider simmer for 20 minutes.

conversation.text: It's simmering now. I'm not sure 20 minutes would be enough for my apple butter. Is there any other way to check?

Do not worry, the 20 minutes is just a preliminary boil, after 20 minutes we then add in the sugar and spices then turn the heat back up to high until the mixture boils again. As soon as it boils we reduce the heat to low again and let it simmer for a further 30 minutes.
evidence: Stir in the sugar and spices,
then turn the heat back up to high. Let the mixture come to a boil.
As soon as the cider starts to boil, reduce the heat to low, and let the apples simmer for 30 minutes.

conversation.text: I see. Can you tell me how much sugar and spice do I need?

Both spice and sugar should be added according to taste preferences however I recommend trying 1 and a half cups (or 300g) of brown sugar and half a cup or (115g) of white sugar for a twist. Alternatively you can add up to 4 cups (900g) if you prefer the apple cider to be sweeter.
evidence: 1½ cups (300 grams) of brown sugar and ½ cup (115 grams) of white sugar.
If you'd like the apple cider to be sweeter, you can add up to 4 cups (900 grams) of sugar.

conversation.text: Thanks! It's very helpful! Now I have simmered the liquid for another 30 minutes.

Okay now your apples should be soft so take the pot off the stove and let the mixture cool down a little. Once cooled you can then mash the apples using a masher or puree them in a blender or food processor.
evidence: Let the mixture cool for a bit, then mash or purée the apples

conversation.text: Just did that. Are we close to the end?

Yes, all you have to do now is put the mash/pureed mixture back into the pot and continue cooking it over low heat for another hour or so, until it thickens. Be sure not to wait too long and make it too thick. You should see about a 40-50 percent reduction in the mixture. Watch out for splatters so have a splatter screen or pot lit handy.
evidence: Return the mixture to the pot, and continue cooking it over low heat until it thickens, about 1 hour.
You don't want the apple butter to be too thick, however; the mixture should be reduced by about 40 to 50%.

conversation.text: Another hour? Okay, this recipe takes a long time lol. How thick does it need to be? Maybe I don't need that much time.
Lol trust me when I say it will all be worth it in the end. It just must not have too much or too little liquid. Once happy with its thickness pour into jars leaving a quarter inch (0.64cm) of space.
evidence: Pour the apple butter into jars, leaving ¼ inch (0.64 centimeters) of space.

conversation.text: Does it need to chill before transferring to the jars?
Yes, let it cool down first then after transferring to your jars, store in the fridge and you are good to go.
evidence: Store the jars in the fridge.

conversation.text: I see. Thanks!
It is a pleasure.

procedure.summary: Wash, peel, core, and quarter the apples.
procedure.description: Wash the apples first, then peel them. After this, you can core them using an apple corer, and then cut them into quarters. If you don't own an apple corer, you can cut them into quarters first, then cut the core away with a knife.

procedure.summary: Put the apples and apple cider into a large pot, bring it to a boil, then simmer it over low heat for 20 minutes.
procedure.description: Put the apples into a large pot first, then add the apple cider. Turn the heat up to high, and let the cider come to a boil. Immediately reduce the heat to low, and let the apples and cider simmer for 20 minutes.

procedure.summary: Add the sugar and spices, return to a boil, then simmer over low heat for 30 minutes.
procedure.description: Stir in the sugar and spices, then turn the heat back up to high. Let the mixture come to a boil. As soon as the cider starts to boil, reduce the heat to low, and let the apples simmer for 30 minutes. For a twist, try 1½ cups (300 grams) of brown sugar and ½ cup (115 grams) of white sugar. If you'd like the apple cider to be sweeter, you can add up to 4 cups (900 grams) of sugar.

procedure.summary: Let the mixture cool for a bit, then mash or purée the apples.
procedure.description: Once the apples are soft, take the pot off the stove, and let the mixture cool down a little. You can then mash the apples using a potato masher, or purée them in a blender or food processor.

procedure.summary: Return the mixture to the pot, and continue cooking it over low heat until it thickens, about 1 hour.
procedure.description: The longer you cook it, the thicker it will become. You don't want the apple butter to be too thick, however; the mixture should be reduced by about 40 to 50%. The apple butter may splatter. Consider keeping a splatter screen of sorts over the pot to keep your kitchen clean.

procedure.summary: Pour the apple butter into jars, leaving ¼ inch (0.64 centimeters) of space.
procedure.description: Wipe the mouths of the jars with a clean towel, then put the lids on. Store the jars in the fridge.
